ODE FOR THE THANKSGIVING DAY. Begin, my Muse, and strike the Lyre! Begin! and lofty Lays inspire, That fading Fame prolong! Canst thou behold the Wonders of this Year? Canst thou the Thanks of rescu'd Nations hear, Yet free from Rapture still forbear thy Song? 'Tis true, Ramillia's Glorious Name Has rais'd the tuneful Sons of Fame, To no ignoble Strain: Thou shalt a more extended Task pursue, Shalt bring far distant Regions to our View, And in one Picture draw the whole Campaign. As when an Eagle mounts on high, The Flocks beneath him trembling lye, Nor dare look up for Fear; The Battel thus the baffled Gaul declines, He doubts his Host, he lurks behind his Lines, Nor dares look out while Marlbrough's Arms appear. But now reviving from his Fears, Once more he moves, once more prepares To meet the daring Foe: He hopes the Gaul, and Boyan Troops combin'd, E'er the fierce Briton's their Allies have join'd, May reap Revenge for Blenheim's dreadful Blow. Marlbrough, who long had wish'd in vain To meet their Armies on the Plain, Sees them prepare for Fight; As the bold Falcon, eager by Delay, By Hunger pinch'd, and raging for her Prey, Sees the fond Quarrey take their Fatal Flight. The moving Host the Heroe warms, Grant we again may meet in Arms! (He cries) in Arms engage! We leave th'Event to Heav'n, let Heav'n decree Whether Mankind shall rest, secure and free, Or still live subject to Tyrannick Rage. Now, by Superior Numbers, Vain, The Gauls a while their Fears restrain, Yet move to Battel slow: The Britons with impetuous Fury run, Prevent the Shock, and make th'Aggressors own, 'Tis Blenheim still where Marlbrough finds a Foe. Blenheim! the Name our Friends must hear With Transport, and our Foes with Fear; Bavaria 'till that Day, Through Towns Imperial, with insulting Scorn Ran like a Flame through Fields of ripen'd Corn, Or Eastern Winds upon an open Sea. As when the Wolf a Herd devours, The Lion that fell Wolf o'er-pow'rs, And stops his furious Course: So when Bavaria tore his Austrian Foe, Marlbrough resolves to make th'Invader know, Of Freemen and of Slaves the diff'rent Force. How can a gen'rous Freeborn Mind Assist a Tyrant, that Mankind Of Native Right deprives? But in Mankind's Defence to waste his Blood, To Perish nobly for the Publick Good, Sure such a Death is worth a Thousand Lives! What are these Nimrods? Goddess say! Monsters that make their Kind their Prey; Heavens dire avenging Rod: But when all Triumph, in a Chief's Success, When ev'n the Vanquish'd does the Victor bless, 'Tis more than Man, 'tis being as a God. Swell'd by fierce Rains, and melted Snow, No Banks can hold th'unruly Po; He flows o'er Lombard Plains, Sweeps Flocks, and Herds, and drives th'astonisht Hind To distant Mountains: Soon an Eastern Wind Repels the Storm, the foaming Flood restrains. Such is the Tyrant's boundless Rage; Tho' nothing can his Wrath asswage, No Laws restrain his Pow'r: Tho' from his Shores th'affrighted Subject flies, Soon some Avenger of Mankind shall rise, And their invaded Liberties restore. While Marlbrough runs the Race of Fame, While Towns Surrender at his Name, And States his Aid implore; Anguish, and secret Grief Eugenio touch, Not Grief to think the Briton does too much, But Grief that He himself can do no more. The Glory of Illustrious Deeds, In Minds ignoble, Envy breeds, They praise them with Regret: 'Tis Emulation fires the Hero's Mind, He takes great Acts as Treasures lent Mankind, And is uneasie 'till he pays the Debt. Expecting Aid, Eugenio's Breast, Anxious, perplex'd, with Rage oppress'd, A Thousand Cares employ: Not with more Rage th'impatient Lover stays, Mad for his destin'd Bride, while dull Delays Of tedious Triflers long retard his Joy. What (cries he) more Excuses still? Can they no Sense of Glory feel? Or are they dead to Shame? Long since the British Queen has sent her Aid, Her Peoples gen'rous Loan long since is paid, And now her Armies lead the Way to Fame. What means that Shout? The Austrians join'd! The Belgian Troops appear behind! Now breaking all Delay, No Fear of Hostile Arms Eugene controlls, Down, like a Torrent, from the Alps he rolls, Nor Towns, nor Floods, nor Armies stop his Way. His Warlike Host, no more confin'd, With Savoy's steadfast Squadrons join'd, Their mutual Shouts rebound: So when the Current of the rapid Rhone Pours in upon the gentle, silent Soane, Their Waters roar, their ecchoing Shoars resound. Savoy, whose fixt, unalter'd Breast, By an impending Ruin prest, Resolv'd and steady stood: Nor won by Promise, nor by Threats deterr'd, Firm to the Cause of Europe's Rights, preferr'd Allies in Glory, to Allies in Blood. Expiring Turin, from her Tow'rs Soon as she views th'approaching Pow'rs, Forgets her Toils, and Grief; Andromeda with such transporting Joy, While the fierce Monster hasten'd to destroy, Saw the bold Perseus Fly to her Relief. With Pleasure sparkling in his Eyes, This is the Time, Eugenio cries, Our Share of Praise to claim: Tho' Marlbrough, Bright and Radiant, like the Sun Has his vast Course of Godlike Glory run, Let Us, like Stars, adorn the Sphere of Fame. Cou'd Our great Actions equal Theirs, Th'Impartial World, that both compares, Must still a Diff'rence find: We Fight, a dire Invader to restrain, We Fight, our Conquer'd Countries to regain, They Fight, uninjur'd, to relieve Mankind. The Double Number of our Foes, The Trenches which their Camp inclose, Render the Brave more Bold: Can Troops like Ours by Dangers be dismay'd? Were e'er a Herd of hungry Wolves afraid, To find too num'rous Flocks within the Fold? He said; amaz'd great Orleans stood, His Arms besmear'd with Royal Blood; Marsin his Sword resign'd; Fueillade in vain would bring his Succours nigh, In vainâthey see, they tremble, and they fly, Dispers'd like Leaves before th'Autumnal Wind! Stop! stop, my Muse, thy daring Flight! Leave Victors to pursue the Fight, Obey the steady Rein! Struck with the Splendor of the Lombard Course, Like an unruly, headstrong, fiery Horse, In thy wild Frenzy, thou hast run by Spain. Turn; turn and see the British Fleet Impatient comes the Gauls to meet; Alas, the Gauls are flown! While a young King by Glorious Anna sent, Stands in the Breaches, resolutely bent To fall in Ruins, or to fix his Throne. The Eclipse on the Day that the Siege of Barcelona was rais'd. Louis look up! look up to Heav'n! The Sun, that Sign thy Pride has giv'n, Behold depriv'd of Light! He shall again with greater Glory rise, With Radiant Splendor grace his Native Skies; Thy Sun eclips'd, 'tis one Eternal Night! See thy Young Anjou Pale, Forlorn; His boasted Troops confus'd, and torn; His Gen'rals in Despair! See how he meanly steals away by Night, Quits Cannon, Baggage, All that stops his Flight; Leaves ev'n his Wounded to his Rival's Care! Prepar'd, th'enrag'd Iberians stood T'avenge their Wrongs with Captive Blood: See Charles that Rage oppose! With Pious Haste that gen'rous Monarch flies, (A soft Compassion melting in his Eyes) Saves ev'n Thy Subjects, now no more His Foes! See next the Cortez, long disus'd, Like thy own injur'd States abus'd, By him conven'd again; Sedate in Council, as in Action Bold. In Flanders, Germany and Spain, behold How different are thy Steps from those of Anne! Ambition leads thy Troops to fight, Nations thou robb'st of Native Right, Thy Schemes to Ruin tend; She rescues Empires for their lawful Lord, By Her each Nation has its Rights restor'd, She fights to save, and conquers to defend. Go on, Great QUEEN, with like Success! Just Heav'n will still that Monarch bless, That injur'd Kingdoms saves: Belov'd by all! serene and calm in Mind! See the detested Troublers of Mankind, Torn by Despair, descending to their Graves! Inspire one Labour more my Muse! For who with Galway can refuse In Fame's bright Paths to go? While He with Soldiers unexpert in War, Form'd by his Toils, and modell'd by his Care, March'd to Madrid attended by the Foe. Sure now the Work's entirely done! What hinders Spain from being won? The Duke of Berwick.A British General there! When Britons Lead, the Gauls themselves can Stand? Oh quit, Brave Youth, that infamous Command! Forbear to Guide thy Country's Foes! forbear! Marsin appears at Dead of Night, Bloody and pale from Lombard Fight, And thus thy Soul alarms: 'Tis done! 'tis written in the Realms of Peace, Louis must fall! Tyrannick Pow'r must cease! And Europe must be freed by British Arms! 'Tis done, and I already see Exulting Nations, Worlds made Free, To Heav'n glad Off'rings pay! Tho' for a while the Sun of Freedom hid, The gloomy Clouds seem hov'ring o'er Madrid; See Rivers comes, and drives those Clouds away! Oh Britons! Since such Things you dare, Factious, divided as you are, To a firm Union come! Let Parties cease! let Kingdoms now Unite! And let not those, whose Actions shine so bright, Conclude All useless who remain at home! While diff'rent Chiefs, with like Success, On ev'ry Side, the Tyrant press, Godolphin All supplies: Ev'n We, who seem in vain to waste our Time, In lofty Numbers, and with Songs sublime, Will place Your daring Heroes in the Skies. Whether the Warriors Trophies raise, Or Poets Sing Immortal Lays, 'Tis ANNA fires each Breast: 'Tis ANNA's Glory that inspires the Muse, 'Tis ANNA's Glory ev'ry Chief pursues, She Chains th'Oppressor, and She Frees th'Opprest. FINIS.
